intro: Anemia wightiana, commonly known as the Wight's anemone, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, white to pinkish flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant has palmately divided leaves and thrives in cool, moist environments. It is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes at high elevations. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many parts of its range.
